User-Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; rv:5.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/5.0
Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; rv:5.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/5.0

In a layout with display:box and box-orient: horizontal, a fixed width on one of the child boxes is ignored, if it contains content that world normally overflow (and be scrolled or clipped). Instead, the box expands to fit the widest child, ignoring the width defined.

Reproducible: Always

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Container box has display: display: -moz-box / -moz-box-orient: horizontal.
2. Child X of Container has fixed width
3. Child Y of X has content that is wider than X's fixed width


Actual Results:  
Width of X expands to contain Y, no overflow/scroll behaviour on Y.

Expected Results:  
Width of X should be as specified in CSS; Contents of Y should overflow or scroll as per its overflow-x property.

Will attach test case...

Created attachment 536626
test case showing incorrect width in FF vs Chrome

This test case demonstrates how the width of the fixed box ('mainbox') is ignored when it is laid out as part of a display: box layout, and contains a 'toowide' element.

The example includes webkit and mozilla CSS prefixes, so demonstrates differing behaviour in FF vs Chrome, where the layout is as expected.
